question: Will the maximum daily average CO₂ reported by the Mauna Loa Observatory for March 1-25, 2025 be less than 429.0 ppm?
reasoning:
Based on the gathered evidence, here are the key points relevant to estimating the probability of the maximum daily average CO₂ level being less than 429.0 ppm for March 1-25, 2025:

1. **Recent CO₂ Levels**: As of February 2025, the monthly average CO₂ level at Mauna Loa was 427.09 ppm. The most recent reading from February 6, 2025, was 428.6 ppm.

2. **Historical Trends**: Historically, each March has had a higher monthly mean CO₂ level than the previous year's March. The period from late September through May is typically a time of rising CO₂ levels due to the Northern Hemisphere's fall and winter.

3. **Current Year Observations**: On March 7, 2025, the daily CO₂ level at Mauna Loa reached 430.60 ppm, setting a new all-time high. This indicates that the CO₂ levels have already surpassed the 429.0 ppm threshold during the period in question.

Given these observations, it is highly unlikely that the maximum daily average CO₂ level for March 1-25, 2025, will be less than 429.0 ppm. The trend of increasing CO₂ levels, combined with the recent record high, suggests that levels will remain above the threshold.

FINAL PROBABILITY: 0.0

| February 2025: | 427.09 ppm |

The graphs show monthly mean carbon dioxide measured at Mauna Loa Observatory, Hawaii.
The carbon dioxide data on Mauna
Loa constitute the longest record of direct measurements of CO2 in the
atmosphere. They were started by C. David Keeling of the Scripps Institution
of Oceanography in March of 1958 at a facility of the National Oceanic and
Atmospheric Administration *[Keeling, 1976]*. NOAA started its own CO2
measurements in May of 1974, and they have run in parallel with those made by
Scripps since then *[Thoning, 1989]*.

The last five complete years of the Mauna Loa CO2 record plus the current year
are shown in the first graph. The full record of combined Scripps data and NOAA data is shown in the second graph.
Every monthly mean is the average of daily means, which are in
turn based on hourly averages, but only for those hours during which “background” conditions
prevail (see [gml.noaa.gov/ccgg/about/co2_measurements.html](https://gml.noaa.gov/ccgg/about/co2_measurements.html) for more information).

The **red** lines and symbols represent the monthly mean values,
centered on the middle of each month. The **black** lines and symbols represent the same,
after correction for the average seasonal cycle. The latter is determined as a moving average of
SEVEN adjacent seasonal cycles centered on the month to be corrected, except for the first and
last THREE and one-half years of the record, where the seasonal cycle has been averaged over the
first and last SEVEN years, respectively.

**CO2 Is The Number to Watch**

When the trend for atmospheric CO2 trend begins to falter and fall, we can expect global average temperature to follow. For those who care about the sustainability of the planet, and who want it to remain a place where people can flourish, the measured CO2 levels in the atmosphere serve as the single best, real-time signal of whether the world as a whole is on track to a safe future, or needing to do more to get on track.

Marking the latest CO2 records is not an act of celebration, but of bearing witness.

The achievements are a sobering reminder of the chemical changes that we humans are collectively making to the atmosphere--changes with disruptive impacts that affect every living being in the biosphere. When a new record is reached, it is is marked here with an invitation for people to take notice, reflect on the transformation that is going in the wrong direction, and resolve to reverse these trends.

Reversing the trend is not something that any one person can achieve on their own. But individuals and groups can build on this CO2 Earth initiative by taking steps that help make the CO2 indicator for planetary health as ubiqutious as our stock market updates and weather reports. Consider sharing the CO2 Earth updates and records with people and groups that are part of your information-sharing circle.



**A New Daily High Each Year**

The graphic below from [Teem Earth partner @NumberLens](https://partner.teem.earth/numberlens/) presents NOAA CO2 readings from1999 to 2020 to show the progression of the seasonal peak for daily CO2 readings at Mauna Loa. It shows that CO2 levels usually peak in April or May, a phenomena discovered by Charles David Keeling in the late 1950s and early 1960s when he began what became the world's longest-running, high preceision record of direct measurements of CO2 in background air. ### Monthly Average Mauna Loa CO2

| February 2025: | 427.09 ppm |
| February 2024: | 424.55 ppm |

The graphs show monthly mean carbon dioxide measured at Mauna Loa Observatory, Hawaii.
The carbon dioxide data on Mauna
Loa constitute the longest record of direct measurements of CO2 in the
atmosphere. They were started by C. David Keeling of the Scripps Institution
of Oceanography in March of 1958 at a facility of the National Oceanic and
Atmospheric Administration *[Keeling, 1976]*. NOAA started its own CO2
measurements in May of 1974, and they have run in parallel with those made by
Scripps since then *[Thoning, 1989]*.

The last five complete years of the Mauna Loa CO2 record plus the current year
are shown in the first graph. The full record of combined Scripps data and NOAA data is shown in the second graph.
Every monthly mean is the average of daily means, which are in
turn based on hourly averages, but only for those hours during which “background” conditions
prevail (see [gml.noaa.gov/ccgg/about/co2_measurements.html](https://gml.noaa.gov/ccgg/about/co2_measurements.html) for more information).

The **red** lines and symbols represent the monthly mean values,
centered on the middle of each month. The **black** lines and symbols represent the same,
after correction for the average seasonal cycle. The latter is determined as a moving average of
SEVEN adjacent seasonal cycles centered on the month to be corrected, except for the first and
last THREE and one-half years of the record, where the seasonal cycle has been averaged over the
first and last SEVEN years, respectively.

The vertical bars on the **black** lines of the first graph show the uncertainty
of each monthly mean based on the observed variability of CO2 in different weather
systems as they go pa…

**CO2 Is The Number to Watch**

When the trend for atmospheric CO2 trend begins to falter and fall, we can expect global average temperature to follow. Marking the latest CO2 records is not an act of celebration, but of bearing witness.

The achievements are a sobering reminder of the chemical changes that we humans are collectively making to the atmosphere--changes with disruptive impacts that affect every living being in the biosphere. When a new record is reached, it is is marked here with an invitation for people to take notice, reflect on the transformation that is going in the wrong direction, and resolve to reverse these trends.

Reversing the trend is not something that any one person can achieve on their own. But individuals and groups can build on this CO2 Earth initiative by taking steps that help make the CO2 indicator for planetary health as ubiqutious as our stock market updates and weather reports. Consider sharing the CO2 Earth updates and records with people and groups that are part of your information-sharing circle.



**A New Daily High Each Year**

The graphic below from [Teem Earth partner @NumberLens](https://partner.teem.earth/numberlens/) presents NOAA CO2 readings from1999 to 2020 to show the progression of the seasonal peak for daily CO2 readings at Mauna Loa. It shows that CO2 levels usually peak in April or May, a phenomena discovered by Charles David Keeling in the late 1950s and early 1960s when he began what became the world's longest-running, high preceision record of direct measurements of CO2 in background air. Read about this in…

messages.content:
Based on the following question, analyze it carefully and provide your probability estimate.

Question: Will the maximum daily average CO₂ reported by the Mauna Loa Observatory for March 1-25, 2025 be less than 429.0 ppm?
Background: *This question is part of the* [*Bridgewater Forecasting Contest*](https://www.metaculus.com/bridgewater/)*. To be eligible to win prizes in the competition you must register for the tournament. The last day to register is March 24, 2025. Sign up or check your registration status* [*here*](https://www.metaculus.com/bridgewater/)*.*

***

The [Mauna Loa Observatory](https://gml.noaa.gov/obop/mlo/), located over 11,000 feet (\~3,400 meters) above sea level on the main island of Hawaii, has been recording atmospheric CO₂ since 1958. In that time, [measured background CO2](https://gml.noaa.gov/ccgg/about/co2_measurements.html) has risen from 313 parts per million (ppm) to the most recent (February 6, 2025) reading of 428.6 ppm, a 37% increase and a phenomenon known as the [Keeling Curve](https://www.acs.org/education/whatischemistry/landmarks/keeling-curve.html): 

![](https://gml.noaa.gov/webdata/ccgg/trends/co2_data_mlo.png)

CO₂ levels have seasonal fluctuations [due to](https://www.universityofcalifornia.edu/news/during-year-extremes-carbon-dioxide-levels-surge-faster-ever) the growing season in the Northern Hemisphere, with the period of late September through May being a period of rising CO₂ coinciding with the northern fall and winter. Since records have been kept at Mauna Loa, each March has had a higher [monthly mean](https://gml.noaa.gov/ccgg/trends/data.html) level of CO₂ than the previous year's March, with the past decade as follows:

| Year | CO₂ ppm | YoY increase |
| ---- | ------- | ------------ |
| 2010 | 391.37  | 0.60%        |
| 2011 | 392.8   | 0.37%        |
| 2012 | 394.59  | 0.46%        |
| 2013 | 397.66  | 0.78%        |
| 2014 | 399.91  | 0.57%        |
| 2015 | 401.74  | 0.46%        |
| 2016 | 405.06  | 0.83%        |
| 2017 | 407.54  | 0.61%        |
| 2018 | 409.59  | 0.50%        |
| 2019 | 412.18  | 0.63%        |
| 2020 | 414.72  | 0.62%        |
| 2021 | 417.61  | 0.70%        |
| 2022 | 418.76  | 0.28%        |
| 2023 | 420.99  | 0.53%        |
| 2024 | 425.38  | 1.04%        |

CO₂ is a [greenhouse gas](https://www.climate.gov/news-features/understanding-climate/climate-change-atmospheric-carbon-dioxide), with a [high correlation](https://www.nature.com/articles/srep21691) between rising CO₂ levels and increased surface temperatures.
Resolution criteria: This question resolves as YES if the maximum daily average carbon dioxide (CO₂) level for the time period March 1, 2025 to March 25, 2025 (inclusive) is less than 429.0 ppm, according to data reported by the Mauna Loa Observatory of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's Global Monitoring Laboratory. (See Fine Print for detailed instructions on accessing the data.)

The question will resolve when the data is assessed by Metaculus on March 28, 2025. Later updates or revisions to the data after the question has resolved are immaterial.
Fine print: If a daily mean for any of the dates is missing on March 28, 2025, resolution will wait until March 31, 2025 for the data to become complete. If at that time 13 or more of the daily means are available, then the question will resolve based on that data. If fewer than 13 daily means for the period in question are available before 5 PM Eastern Time on March 31, 2025, then this question will be **annulled**.

DETAILED INSTRUCTIONS TO ACCESS DATA:

1. Go to "Trends in Atmospheric Carbon Dioxide (CO₂)" for Mauna Loa, Hawaii [here](https://gml.noaa.gov/ccgg/trends/data.html) and access the "Data" tab.
2. Download the "Mauna Loa CO₂ daily means" CSV file.
3. Column A corresponds to the year, Column B corresponds to the month number (March is 3), and Column C corresponds to the date.
4. Column E is the CO₂ reading for each date.
5. Resolution amount will be the maximum CO₂ reading for the dates March 1, 2025 through March 25, 2025. The Excel/Google Sheets command is MAX, so for example if the data appears in rows 15610 through 15634, the formula is =max(E15610:E15634).

# Trends in CO2, CH4, N2O, SF6


## Trends in Atmospheric Carbon Dioxide (CO2)

### Monthly Average Mauna Loa CO2

| February 2025: | 427.09 ppm |
| February 2024: | 424.55 ppm |

The graphs show monthly mean carbon dioxide measured at Mauna Loa Observatory, Hawaii.
The carbon dioxide data on Mauna
Loa constitute the longest record of direct measurements of CO2 in the
atmosphere. They were started by C. David Keeling of the Scripps Institution
of Oceanography in March of 1958 at a facility of the National Oceanic and
Atmospheric Administration *[Keeling, 1976]*. NOAA started its own CO2
measurements in May of 1974, and they have run in parallel with those made by
Scripps since then *[Thoning, 1989]*.

The last five complete years of the Mauna Loa CO2 record plus the current year
are shown in the first graph. The full record of combined Scripps data and NOAA data is shown in the second graph.
Every monthly mean is the average of daily means, which are in
turn based on hourly averages, but only for those hours during which “background” conditions
prevail (see [gml.noaa.gov/ccgg/about/co2_measurements.html](https://gml.noaa.gov/ccgg/about/co2_measurements.html) for more information).

The **red** lines and symbols represent the monthly mean values,
centered on the middle of each month. The **black** lines and symbols represent the same,
after correction for the average seasonal cycle. The latter is determined as a moving average of
SEVEN adjacent seasonal cycles centered on the month to be corrected, except for the first and
last THREE and one-half years of the record, where the seasonal cycle has been averaged over the
first and last SEVEN years, respectively.

The vertical bars on the **black** lines of the first graph show the uncertainty
of each monthly mean based on the observed variability of CO2 in different weather
systems as they go pa…

This table presents the latest, daily average reading for atmospheric CO2 on the planet. Updates happen once a day with few exceptions.


**CO2 Is The Number to Watch**

When the trend for atmospheric CO2 trend begins to falter and fall, we can expect global average temperature to follow. For those who care about the sustainability of the planet, and who want it to remain a place where people can flourish, the measured CO2 levels in the atmosphere serve as the single best, real-time signal of whether the world as a whole is on track to a safe future, or needing to do more to get on track.

** Mauna Loa record includes CO2 measurments at Maunakea site in 2022-2023 ** Record high for the institution, not for CO2 measurements at Mauna Loa*


Marking the latest CO2 records is not an act of celebration, but of bearing witness.

The achievements are a sobering reminder of the chemical changes that we humans are collectively making to the atmosphere--changes with disruptive impacts that affect every living being in the biosphere. When a new record is reached, it is is marked here with an invitation for people to take notice, reflect on the transformation that is going in the wrong direction, and resolve to reverse these trends.

Reversing the trend is not something that any one person can achieve on their own. But individuals and groups can build on this CO2 Earth initiative by taking steps that help make the CO2 indicator for planetary health as ubiqutious as our stock market updates and weather reports. Consider sharing the CO2 Earth updates and records with people and groups that are part of your information-sharing circle.



**A New Daily High Each Year**

The graphic below from [Teem Earth partner @NumberLens](https://partner.teem.earth/numberlens/) presents NOAA CO2 readings from1999 to 2020 to show the progression of the seasonal peak for daily CO2 readings at Mauna Loa. It shows that CO2 levels usually peak in April or May, a phenomena discovered by Charles David Keeling in the late 1950s and early 1960s when he began what became the world's longest-running, high preceision record of direct measurements of CO2 in background air. Read about this in…

In that time, measured background CO2 has risen from 313 parts per million (ppm) to the most recent (February 6, 2025) reading of 428.6 ppm, a 37% increase and a phenomenon known as the Keeling Curve. CO₂ levels have seasonal fluctuations due to the growing season in the Northern Hemisphere, with the period of late September through May being a period of rising CO₂ coinciding with the northern fall and winter. messages.content:
Based on the gathered evidence, here are the key points relevant to estimating the probability of the maximum daily average CO₂ level being less than 429.0 ppm for March 1-25, 2025:

1. **Recent CO₂ Levels**: As of February 2025, the monthly average CO₂ level at Mauna Loa was 427.09 ppm. The most recent reading from February 6, 2025, was 428.6 ppm.

2. **Historical Trends**: Historically, each March has had a higher monthly mean CO₂ level than the previous year's March. The period from late September through May is typically a time of rising CO₂ levels due to the Northern Hemisphere's fall and winter.

3. **Current Year Observations**: On March 7, 2025, the daily CO₂ level at Mauna Loa reached 430.60 ppm, setting a new all-time high. This indicates that the CO₂ levels have already surpassed the 429.0 ppm threshold during the period in question.

Given these observations, it is highly unlikely that the maximum daily average CO₂ level for March 1-25, 2025, will be less than 429.0 ppm. The trend of increasing CO₂ levels, combined with the recent record high, suggests that levels will remain above the threshold.

FINAL PROBABILITY: 0.0
